August 17, 1980: Fiction
RAGE OF ANGELS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $12.95.) An idealistic young
woman lawyer triumphs over two vengeful men.
THE SPIKE, by Arnaud de Borchgrave and Robert Moss. (Crown, $12.95.)
Newsman on the trail of a Soviet conspiracy.
RANDOM WINDS, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $11.95.) Three generations of
doctors and their families.
THE BOURNE IDENTITY, by Robert Ludlum. (Richard Marek, $12.95.) The
melodramatic adventures of an amnesiac trying to find out who he really is.
KANE & ABEL, by Jeffrey Archer. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Battles in a
corporation boardroom between new money and old.
SINS OF THE FATHERS, by Susan Howatch. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.)
Rivalries and intrigue in the family of a ruthless tycoon.
PRINCESS DAISY, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $12.95.) The fight for survival in the
world of glitter, from the Czar's St. Petersburg to Manhattan's SoHo.
THE NINJA, by Eric Van Lustbader. (M. Evans, $12.95.) The erotic side of the
Japanese samurai tradition.
SOLO, by Jack Higgins. (Stein & Day, $11.95.) Exploits of a famous concert
pianist who secretly is an international hit man.
THE SECOND COMING, by Walker Percy. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95.) A
retired lawyer finds a new life through an attractive young neighbor.
NO LOVE LOST, by Helen Van Slyke. (Lippincott, $10.95.) Three New York
society women learn to cope with marriage and men.
THE DEVIL'S ALTERNATIVE, by Frederick Forsyth. (Viking, $12.95.) Countdown
to global doom in 1982.
INNOCENT BLOOD, by P.D. James. (Scribner's, $10.95.) A veteran whodunit
writer now investigates the mysteries of family life.
THE CRADLE WILL FALL, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) A
young woman investigator on the trail of a scandal in suburbia.
GREEN MONDAY, by Michael M. Thomas. (Wyndham Books, $12.95.)
Clandestine international plot threatens America's economic and political future.
August 17, 1980
Non-Fiction
SHELLEY: ALSO KNOWN AS SHIRLEY, by Shelley Winters. (Morrow, $14.95.) A
Brooklyn ghetto girl's progress to three homes, two Oscars, six mink coats and
ninety-nine films.
FREE TO CHOOSE, by Milton & Rose Friedman. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich,
$9.95.) The Nobel laureate economist and his wife discuss the relationship of
government and the economy: tie-in to the current PBS television series.
THY NEIGHBOR'S WIFE, by Gay Talese. (Doubleday, $14.95.) How American
sexuality has changed in our time.
LITTLE GLORIA ... HAPPY AT LAST, by Barbara Goldsmith. (Knopf, $15.95.) The
family struggle to gain possession of young Gloria Vanderbilt and her fortune.
MEN IN LOVE, by Nancy Friday. (Delacorte, $12.95.) Men's fantasies about
women and sex.
THE REAL WAR, by Richard Nixon. (Warner Books, $12.50.) A grim view of the
situation of the United States and the world.
THE THIRD WAVE, by Alvin Toffler. (Morrow, $14.95.) The changes our society is
about to undergo: a pop prognosticator's analysis.
ANATOMY OF AN ILLNESS, by Norman Cousins. (Norton, $9.95.) A patient's
account of his successful fight against a serious disease.
CHINA MEN, by Maxine Hong Kingston. (Knopf, $10.95.) A Chinese-American
woman's effort to understand the men in her heritage.
NOTHING DOWN, by Robert G. Allen. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) How to buy
real estate with little or no cash.
JIM FIXX'S SECOND BOOK OF RUNNING, by James F. Fixx. (Random House,
$10.) More advice for both beginners and marathoners.
THE BRETHREN, by Bob Woodward and Scott Armstrong. (Simon & Schuster,
$13.95.) Inside the Supreme Court.
DONAHUE, by Phil Donahue. (Simon & Schuster, $11.95.) The host of the
popular television talk show tells his life story.
HEARTSOUNDS, by Martha Weinman Lear. (Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) Life with
a dying husband.
HOW YOU CAN BECOME FINANCIALLY INDEPENDENT BY INVESTING IN
REAL ESTATE, by Albert J. Lowry. (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) How-to.
